title: Sam Billings reacts to being named England vice-captain for New Zealand tour
text:
Sam Billings has been appointed England’s T20 vice-captain for the New Zealand tour (Picture: Getty)

Sam Billings insists it is a ‘huge honour’ to be named England’s vice-captain for the five-match IT20 series in New Zealand.

With Morgan’s regular vice-skipper Jos Buttler rested from the tour after a gruelling summer, Billings has been appointed Eoin Morgan’s deputy.

Billings has captained Kent for the past two years and is determined to impress as he looks to secure a place at next year’s T20 World Cup.

England arrived in New Zealand at the start of the week (Picture: Getty)

‘It’s great to get some recognition and it’s a huge honour,’ Billings said ahead of England’s opening T20 warm-up match against a New Zealand XI on Sunday.

‘It’s a great opportunity to be recognised as a developing leader. And there’s an element of personal development about it, too.

‘Eoin gave me a call a couple of weeks ago and said he’d love me to do it. I suppose he must see something in me.

‘I’m looking forward to learning from him and implementing what I’ve done at Kent. But I’m in the side as a batsman first and foremost and then as a keeper.

‘You have to be able to perform at that top level consistently in those roles first. I just have to make the most out of every opportunity.

‘For me, as a player, my focus is on being in that T20 World Cup squad.’

Eoin Morgan was keen for Billings to act as his deputy (Picture: Getty)

Billings missed last summer’s World Cup after dislocating his shoulder while playing for Kent but scored three successive hundreds on his return to county cricket at the end of the season.

At the age of 28, Billings is still hoping to cement a place in England’s one-day teams and added: ‘I’ve been on the fringes for the last four or five years.

‘I’ve made some performances along the way, but we have such depth in our squad in terms of batsmen and keepers.

📸 Our IT20 squad in New Zealand! 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿🏏 Team for the first warm up game: Bairstow, Banton, Vince, Morgan, Denly, Billings, Sam Curran, Rashid, Jordan, Mahmood, Brown. pic.twitter.com/YxOMH128h7 — England Cricket (@englandcricket) October 25, 2019

‘Even though that innings in the West Indies was a long time ago, it’s about continuing that momentum in an England shirt.

‘For me, it’s about enjoying it and it’s good to be back playing. The injury has given me some perspective.’

After the T20 series, Chris Silverwood’s England face New Zealand in two Tests before heading to South Africa in December and January.
